page.title: 20Fen Ditton Surgery
page.content: The Fen Ditton surgery is held each Tuesday morning in a small terraced house containing two bedrooms, two downstairs rooms and an extension with kitchen, bathroom and toilet. The house is occupied by Mr. and Mrs. Tuck and their two teen-age daughters. On surgery day the lounge becomes the waiting-room and the dining-room becomes the surgery, with the dining- table serving as the doctor's desk. A bureau serves as a medicine cabinet in which some drugs are stored, so that at all other times it must remain locked. The doctor washes his hands when necessary in the kitchen sink. His main surgery is at Milton. Through an intercom system, some local elderly people can indirectly contact Mrs. Tuck if they are ill. She then visits them and alerts the doctor if she feels it is necessary.
